Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Transposable element dynamics across reproductive modes and ploidy levels in natural populations
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project investigates how an important kind of mutation (transposable elements) is impacted by reproductive mode and the number of chromosome sets in a cell. Transposable elements (often called "jumping genes") are sequences of DNA that self-replicate across genomes. They can contribute to genome expansion and are a source for rapid adaptive evolution. In addition, transposable elements are found in all organisms and likely play central roles in evolution, but how chromosome number (or other factors) influences the accumulation and evolution of transposable elements is unclear. This project addresses these fundamental questions and is relevant to all scientists interested in genome structure. Researchers are also involved in Project Lead the Way to develop genomic and molecular evolution lessons for high school students.

A pool-sequencing approach will be applied to a New Zealand freshwater snail, Potamopygus anitopodarum, to test the effects of reproductive mode and ploidy level on transposable elements' evolutionary dynamics. This snail species is ideally suited for the project because otherwise similar coexisting snails vary in reproductive mode and ploidy. Whole-genome sequencing of pools of individuals is a cost-effective means for addressing population genomic questions and enables this novel test of genome-wide effects of reproductive mode and ploidy on the evolutionary dynamics of transposable elements.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We used this National Science Foundation (NSF) support to investigate how genomes – an organism’s entire set of genetic information – are affected by clonal reproduction. Most complex organisms reproduce in a way that makes offspring that are genetically different from one another and their parents. Even though that process of reproduction is more complicated than clonal reproduction – producing genetically identical offspring – it may have a variety of evolutionary benefits. We still do not have a general understanding of why clonal reproduction is so rare, making this question one of the most important for biology. An important part of addressing that question is to learn about how clonal reproduction affects genome evolution. We studied a species of freshwater snail from New Zealand, Potamopyrgus antipodarum to ask how clonal reproduction influences genome evolution. This snail is particularly useful for this question because clonal reproduction has evolved multiple times in its natural populations, meaning that we can compare how clonal snails evolve and function in their environment compared to snails that produce genetically variable offspring.

 Some parts of the genome evolve rapidly, especially sequences that are repeated many times, such as transposable elements and ribosomal RNA genes. Transposable elements (TEs; “jumping genes”) are sequences of DNA that self-replicate within genomes. TEs are found in all organisms and likely play central roles in evolution. Ribosomal RNA (rRNA) genes make up part of the ribosome, the cellular machine of making proteins. rRNA genes are repeated tandemly, sometimes hundreds or thousands of times in a genome. The number of sequence copies can vary among individuals of the same species. Changes in copy number for TEs and rRNA genes from one generation to the next represent a type of mutation. We had previously found that clonal versions of P. antipodarum have many more copies of rRNA genes than their more genetically variable counterparts but we did not know how quickly these new copies accumulate or how much variation is present in a given population. To address these questions - of fundamental importance to understanding evolution - we needed to compare much larger samples of snails from similar versus different genetic backgrounds. With these NSF funds, we traveled to New Zealand to collect snails for whole-genome sequencing. Using genetic markers, we determined genetic relatedness among the snails we collected from two lakes, and then sequenced whole genomes for 12 clonal snails: 2 clonal lineages for each lake, and 3 snails per clonal lineage. With these sequence data we found that the number of rRNA gene copies was highly consistent within clonal lineages but very different between clonal lineages. The implications of this result were that the sequence is reliably passed on to offspring but can change in a very short evolutionary timescale. We are continuing to use these data to determine the extent to which the TEs and other types of mutations vary within and across clonal lineages to better understand how different genetic changes are affected by clonal reproduction. These results offer an important view into the ways that clonal reproduction can affect repetitive sequences like rRNA genes. Our findings also highlight that, counter to assumptions, genetic variation can be rapidly generated with clonal reproduction.
